quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: When superheroes discover what their superpowers actually are, they wreak havoc and they make a mess, and it's uncomfortable.
quotes.speaker: Donna Lichaw
quotes.context: Reframes early-stage growth as inherently messy, normalizing discomfort as a signal you’re uncovering real strengths.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Pull your superpowers out of your stories from your past, your present, and then eventually figure out how to apply them and transpose them to your future.
quotes.speaker: Donna Lichaw
quotes.context: Offers a practical method for identifying strengths by mining personal narratives and then translating them into future action.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: The most effective stories are the ones that we tell ourselves. They may or may not be true; our brain doesn't know the difference.
quotes.speaker: Donna Lichaw
quotes.context: Highlights self-narrative as a powerful lever for behavior change, regardless of objective truth.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Once you can really understand that, you may as well leverage it to be that hero.
quotes.speaker: Donna Lichaw
quotes.context: Turns the self-story insight into an explicit call to intentionally craft an empowering identity and act from it.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Customers always seem to want to give you their data in the messiest possible CSV file, and building a spreadsheet importer becomes a never ending sync for your engineering and support resources.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (OneSchema)
quotes.context: Highlights a common product reality and the operational cost of underestimating data-import complexity.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: You keep adding features to your spreadsheet importer, the customers keep running into issues; six months later, you're fixing yet another date conversion edge case bug.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (OneSchema)
quotes.context: A vivid example of how “just build it in-house” can turn into an ongoing maintenance trap.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Customers get frustrated by useless messages like Error Online 53 and never end up getting started with your product.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (OneSchema)
quotes.context: Actionable reminder that poor error UX can directly block activation and onboarding success.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: In-app communication has the highest conversion, highest engagement, and highest satisfaction of any communication channel.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Sendbird)
quotes.context: A strong channel-selection claim that can influence where teams invest for engagement and retention.

quotes.topic_title: Donna’s origin story into executive coaching
quotes.text: Honestly, storytelling is not going to fix our problems. This is silly.
quotes.speaker: Donna Lichaw
quotes.context: A blunt pushback that challenges the common belief that better storytelling alone solves leadership and influence issues.

quotes.topic_title: Donna’s origin story into executive coaching
quotes.text: When that happens, and I talk about this in the book a bunch, no one wants to hear your stories. You have to actually be able to connect with people and to work with people and feel good as a leader in order to really step up and lead.
quotes.speaker: Donna Lichaw
quotes.context: A practical leadership model: relational connection and internal leadership confidence are prerequisites for storytelling to land.

quotes.topic_title: Donna’s origin story into executive coaching
quotes.text: I didn't have an answer for this team at the time, and I left this offsite just honestly feeling terrible and not knowing what to do about it except telling them, "I think you got to go work with a coach because this is beyond my pay grade."
quotes.speaker: Donna Lichaw
quotes.context: A concrete example of recognizing when a team’s challenges require coaching-level intervention rather than skills training.

quotes.topic_title: Donna’s origin story into executive coaching
quotes.text: Telling stories was not the answer, and so I ended up spending what now is the next decade figuring out, all right, how do you become an effective leader?
quotes.speaker: Donna Lichaw
quotes.context: A clear reframing from “storytelling skill” to the deeper question of what actually makes leaders effective.

quotes.topic_title: Why personal stories shape leadership effectiveness
quotes.text: We all as humans want to be the hero of our own story. It's how we live our lives, it's how we make choices, it's how we understand the world around us, and it's how we communicate back to the world.
quotes.speaker: Donna Lichaw
quotes.context: Frames a practical leadership lens: people’s decisions and communication are driven by an internal “hero narrative.”

quotes.topic_title: Why personal stories shape leadership effectiveness
quotes.text: With leadership, it's much the same, which is we have a mission that we want to accomplish. No matter how big or small, it's something; we're driven to do something.
quotes.speaker: Donna Lichaw
quotes.context: Connects leadership effectiveness to story structure by defining leadership as mission-driven action.

quotes.topic_title: Why personal stories shape leadership effectiveness
quotes.text: And the biggest thing is stories that we tell people, it's like the tip of the iceberg.
quotes.speaker: Donna Lichaw
quotes.context: Counterintuitive reminder that external storytelling matters less than the deeper internal narratives shaping behavior.

quotes.topic_title: Why personal stories shape leadership effectiveness
quotes.text: But the most effective stories are the ones that we experience as we live life and that we tell ourselves as well because we have the ability by saying things like, "Oh, I'll never succeed," or, "Oh, she'll never go for it," or, "He's such a jerk." Or whatever the stories are, these are all stories.
quotes.speaker: Donna Lichaw
quotes.context: Actionable cue to notice and label self-talk and judgments as “stories” you can interrogate and rewrite.

quotes.topic_title: Why personal stories shape leadership effectiveness
quotes.text: And they may or may not be true, they're usually not true, but our brain doesn't know the difference.
quotes.speaker: Donna Lichaw
quotes.context: Highlights a leverage point for change: internal narratives can drive outcomes regardless of factual accuracy.

quotes.topic_title: Inside-out leadership: start with yourself first
quotes.text: But what I learned is that it doesn't work that way. And you need to flip that, which is when you start with you first at the center of the equation, and then I'm going to do... Everything for me is a diagram. I'm thinking of concentric circles.
quotes.speaker: Donna Lichaw
quotes.context: Challenges the common “it’s not about you” leadership mantra and introduces an inside-out starting point.

quotes.topic_title: Inside-out leadership: start with yourself first
quotes.text: Ken Blanchard has a great model for this where you start with you, it's the inner circle, then you are able to lead yourself, then you can lead others. It extends to one-on-one relationships. Then once you've got that, you're able to lead groups, teams, and then outward towards the business.
quotes.speaker: Donna Lichaw
quotes.context: Provides a practical concentric-circles framework for sequencing leadership development from self to organization.

quotes.topic_title: Inside-out leadership: start with yourself first
quotes.text: When you figure that out and you come from the inside out, it's much, much more powerful because it's not selfish like I would've thought years ago, but it's purposeful.
quotes.speaker: Donna Lichaw
quotes.context: Reframes self-focused leadership work as purpose-driven rather than selfish, making it easier to adopt.

quotes.topic_title: Inside-out leadership: start with yourself first
quotes.text: You need fuel from somewhere. And if it comes from without, it's like an eggshell that's just ready to crack. It's not sustainable if it comes from outside.
quotes.speaker: Donna Lichaw
quotes.context: A memorable metaphor explaining why external validation is fragile and why internal purpose is a more durable source of motivation.

quotes.topic_title: Case study: CEO rewrites limiting self-stories
quotes.text: take a data-driven approach to the stories that you tell yourself.
quotes.speaker: Donna Lichaw
quotes.context: A practical methodology: treat self-narratives like hypotheses you can validate with evidence.

quotes.topic_title: Case study: CEO rewrites limiting self-stories
quotes.text: I went out there and talked to his team.
quotes.speaker: Donna Lichaw
quotes.context: Concrete action step: gather direct feedback from the people who experience your leadership.

quotes.topic_title: Case study: CEO rewrites limiting self-stories
quotes.text: And the problem with stories like that is they end up taking over your identity, they shadow and cloud your every day and actions you take and interactions you have with people. And when you focus on them so much, they very well will become true.
quotes.speaker: Donna Lichaw
quotes.context: Explains the self-fulfilling mechanism of limiting beliefs and why they’re so costly to leave unchallenged.

quotes.topic_title: Case study: CEO rewrites limiting self-stories
quotes.text: it's not that they weren't listening to him, but when you're hiring super senior, whip smart executives to work for you, they don't want to be told what to do, they want to have a grand vision that they're excited about, they want maybe some goals to latch onto and help possibly with a strategy to get there, although probably they can got the strategy all on their own.
quotes.speaker: Donna Lichaw
quotes.context: Reframes “lack of respect” as a leadership/role-design mismatch: senior execs want vision and autonomy, not directives.

quotes.topic_title: Case study: CEO rewrites limiting self-stories
quotes.text: It was exactly like user research of any kind or customer discovery, which is you find out what could be possible from your customers and then ideally you co-create a better ending together.
quotes.speaker: Donna Lichaw
quotes.context: A memorable mental model: apply product discovery methods to leadership and personal story rewrites.

quotes.topic_title: When the story is true: quiet leader example
quotes.text: There are times when the stories that we tell ourselves are true. And when we go out and find out what's possible, it is something that we're doing that needs to change or isn't working.
quotes.speaker: Donna Lichaw
quotes.context: Highlights the practical move of validating self-stories with external feedback and being willing to change when the data supports it.

quotes.topic_title: When the story is true: quiet leader example
quotes.text: And this is becoming a problem because she was so quiet that her team thought she was not interested in them.
quotes.speaker: Donna Lichaw
quotes.context: A concrete example of how a behavior can be accurately perceived as a performance issue due to its impact on others.

quotes.topic_title: When the story is true: quiet leader example
quotes.text: what they really needed from her was to know that she was listening to them and that she actually heard them and was going to do something about it, and that she was quiet in these meetings, she was not checked out.
quotes.speaker: Donna Lichaw
quotes.context: Reframes the problem from “talk more” to “signal listening and follow-through,” which is a more actionable and accurate target.

quotes.topic_title: When the story is true: quiet leader example
quotes.text: And the irony of establishing those lines of communication with your team when they're not getting what they need is that you often end up doing the thing that you've been trying to do but failing to do anyway.
quotes.speaker: Donna Lichaw
quotes.context: A counterintuitive observation that improving meta-communication can indirectly fix the original behavior gap.

quotes.topic_title: When the story is true: quiet leader example
quotes.text: This is something that, it's not in the book, but you might've heard of this idea of a personal OS that a lot of us like to have, which is, "Hey, these are my work styles. This is how I process, this is how I do things. These are great ways to work with me, and here's how I'd love to work with you."
quotes.speaker: Donna Lichaw
quotes.context: Introduces a reusable collaboration framework (“personal OS”) for making work styles explicit and improving team alignment.

quotes.topic_title: Imposter syndrome as a functional signal
quotes.text: Certain stories we tell ourselves are actually quite functional and do not necessarily need to be rewritten.
quotes.speaker: Donna Lichaw
quotes.context: Reframes imposter syndrome (and other self-stories) as potentially useful signals rather than problems to eliminate.

quotes.topic_title: Imposter syndrome as a functional signal
quotes.text: but what if you took a counter-intuitive approach and looked at that story, I'm an imposter, and instead asked, "Okay, that's a good story. How is that serving you?"
quotes.speaker: Donna Lichaw
quotes.context: Offers a practical diagnostic question to turn imposter feelings into actionable self-understanding.

quotes.topic_title: Imposter syndrome as a functional signal
quotes.text: And I always think of habits as an itch. If you have an itch, you scratch it, you feel better. There's a reason why we scratch itches; it feels better. If you do it too much, it hurts.
quotes.speaker: Donna Lichaw
quotes.context: Provides a memorable mental model for why unhelpful patterns persist and how they become harmful when overused.

quotes.topic_title: Imposter syndrome as a functional signal
quotes.text: what she realized is that every time it kicked in, she worked harder. And it just meant she was hitting some kind of a growth edge.
quotes.speaker: Donna Lichaw
quotes.context: Gives a concrete example of imposter syndrome functioning as a trigger for learning and growth.

quotes.topic_title: Imposter syndrome as a functional signal
quotes.text: But I think that the trick is, with imposter syndrome, to not deny it, to embrace it as much as you can, but not embrace it so much that it ends up holding you back.
quotes.speaker: Donna Lichaw
quotes.context: Defines a balanced operating principle: use the signal without letting it drive overwork or burnout.

quotes.topic_title: Kryptonite: weaknesses that can be leveraged
quotes.text: They're the kinds that you should avoid and can avoid. For example, scheduling things is my kryptonite, but I do meetings for a living. And I love being in meetings, strangely, and so not scheduling is not an option, but there are ways around it. I automate everything. And some people hire assistants. And there are ways to do it. That's the kind that you're better off avoiding.
quotes.speaker: Donna Lichaw
quotes.context: A practical distinction between weaknesses to design around (automation/assistants) versus trying to “fix” them.

quotes.topic_title: Kryptonite: weaknesses that can be leveraged
quotes.text: I work with a lot of founders, CEOs and senior executives who are dyslexic. It's very, very, very common, especially for CEOs.
quotes.speaker: Donna Lichaw
quotes.context: A specific example/data point that reframes a perceived impairment as common among top leaders.

quotes.topic_title: Kryptonite: weaknesses that can be leveraged
quotes.text: I think kryptonite, the inner kind of kryptonite, that's how I like to think of it, which is you think it makes you weak, but when you can look at how it serves you, it's often not the case.
quotes.speaker: Donna Lichaw
quotes.context: A mental model for reinterpreting “inner kryptonite” as a potential strength by examining its upside.

quotes.topic_title: Kryptonite: weaknesses that can be leveraged
quotes.text: Everything, just look at how it serves you. It's the kind you need to avoid, the kind of kryptonite that you need to really look at and embrace. And once you embrace it, just like with the superheroes, it becomes ideally something that's useful in small doses like Superman, or it could be something more like Hulk, which is you could say his kryptonite is his anger, but that's also his superpower.
quotes.speaker: Donna Lichaw
quotes.context: A “dosage and context” framework: some weaknesses should be avoided, while others should be embraced and used deliberately.

quotes.topic_title: Superpowers: why strengths-based leadership works
quotes.text: The flip side of kryptonite is a superpower.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for reframing weaknesses as clues to where your real strengths lie.

quotes.topic_title: Superpowers: why strengths-based leadership works
quotes.text: I'm a big believer in this, you are too, of just how important it is to lean into your strengths and identify what you're better at than most people and use that as your way of getting ahead versus trying to, say, just remove these kryptonite/things you're not good.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to focus on leveraging standout strengths rather than spending effort fixing weaknesses.

quotes.topic_title: Superpowers: why strengths-based leadership works
quotes.text: I'm never going to be an amazing public speaker. I hate that stuff. Even though I do this podcast, it's not my strength. And it turns out I much prefer writing and sitting there and thinking, and that's what led to this newsletter. I started doing the thing that was pulling me and was easier for me and ends up being really successful because that's another way of achieving the same thing, it turns out.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete example of choosing a strengths-aligned medium (writing) to achieve the same outcomes as a weaker one (speaking).

quotes.topic_title: Superpowers: why strengths-based leadership works
quotes.text: On the one hand, there's so many studies that show that when we play to our strengths, we're much more effective than when we try to fix what's broken. It's a waste of energy to fix what's broken for the most part.
quotes.speaker: Donna Lichaw
quotes.context: A contrarian, research-backed argument that fixing weaknesses is often an inefficient use of energy compared to amplifying strengths.

quotes.topic_title: Superpowers: why strengths-based leadership works
quotes.text: Play to your strengths and good things happen. I could get better at writing emails, but you know what? Not worth my time. And you could have more meetings, and not worth your time either.
quotes.speaker: Donna Lichaw
quotes.context: Practical advice to deliberately avoid “improving” low-leverage weaknesses when you can design work around strengths instead.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Sprig is an AI-powered platform that enables you to collect relevant product experience insights from the right users so you can make product decisions quickly and confidently.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights an actionable approach to speeding up product decision-making by systematically collecting targeted user insights.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: It all starts with Sprig's precise targeting, which allows you to trigger in-app studies based on users' characteristics and actions taken in product.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Provides a concrete methodology for running in-app research by targeting users based on who they are and what they do.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: They're the only platform with product-level AI, meaning it analyzes data across all of your studies to centralize the most important product opportunities, trends, and correlations in one real-time feed.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Describes a mental model for synthesizing research: aggregate across studies to surface opportunities, trends, and correlations in one place.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: there's this very heavy misconception that when you are again catapulted into some kind of senior leadership position, that you're supposed to be a certain way and you're supposed to be loud and opinionated and controlling and tell people what to do, but I've worked with some amazing CEOs who are just incredible listeners instead.
quotes.speaker: Donna Lichaw
quotes.context: Challenges conventional leadership stereotypes with a counterexample that effective CEOs can lead through listening rather than forcefulness.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: they embrace what works for them and they don't try to be what they're supposed to be.
quotes.speaker: Donna Lichaw
quotes.context: Actionable advice for leaders to lean into authentic strengths instead of conforming to an expected leadership persona.

quotes.topic_title: How to identify your superpowers from stories
quotes.text: I've worked with some amazing CEOs who are just incredible listeners instead. And it's the same thing, which is they embrace what works for them and they don't try to be what they're supposed to be.
quotes.speaker: Donna Lichaw
quotes.context: Challenges the stereotype of what leadership must look like and encourages leaning into authentic strengths.

quotes.topic_title: How to identify your superpowers from stories
quotes.text: And I don't find it useful because if I just get a list of things, I will never remember what the list is. And it also has no context for me, and so what I do and what I find works better for my clients as well is to pull your superpowers out of your stories from your past and your present, and then eventually figure out how to apply them and transpose them to your future.
quotes.speaker: Donna Lichaw
quotes.context: Offers a practical alternative to strengths tests: extracting strengths from personal narratives and applying them forward.

quotes.topic_title: How to identify your superpowers from stories
quotes.text: But if you look at your peak experiences from your past, I would go back to when you were a kid, what's something you did when you were a kid, like a project you worked on or something you were a part of that completely, totally lit you up and that you were so excited about? And I would then look at something from your more recent past. What's a project or something you worked on in the last maybe 10 years that just jazzed you up and you were just so excited to do? And then I would also look at just how did you get into your line of work, the thing that you're doing now? What's that meandering path?
quotes.speaker: Donna Lichaw
quotes.context: Gives a step-by-step prompt set for identifying superpowers by triangulating across childhood, recent work, and career path.

quotes.topic_title: How to identify your superpowers from stories
quotes.text: And when you can look at these three stories as moments in time and you can lay them on top of one another, what you see at key moments is your superpowers popping through.
quotes.speaker: Donna Lichaw
quotes.context: Introduces a memorable method: overlay multiple life stories to reveal recurring strengths.

quotes.topic_title: How to identify your superpowers from stories
quotes.text: But when we looked at her past and her stories, what we were able to pull out is that she was really great at connecting things together, connecting themes, connecting pieces, trends and connecting people; connecting ideas together, and then connecting people to ideas.
quotes.speaker: Donna Lichaw
quotes.context: Concrete example of reframing misdiagnosed feedback (“attention to detail”) into a clearer, more useful superpower (“connector”).

quotes.topic_title: Live coaching: Lenny’s peak experiences and themes
quotes.text: It doesn't have to be happy or sad, it's just you were at your best. It lit you up.
quotes.speaker: Donna Lichaw
quotes.context: Reframes “peak experiences” as moments of being at your best (not just positive memories), making the exercise more broadly useful and actionable.

quotes.topic_title: Live coaching: Lenny’s peak experiences and themes
quotes.text: But if you were to unpack at least three of those scenarios, you would find themes.
quotes.speaker: Donna Lichaw
quotes.context: Gives a practical methodology—analyze at least three peak stories—to reliably surface recurring drivers and strengths.

quotes.topic_title: Live coaching: Lenny’s peak experiences and themes
quotes.text: And so that's how you end up using them, which is you really look at, all right, from here to where I now want to go, how can I use this? And what do I need to watch out for if I'm going to over index and use this too much?
quotes.speaker: Donna Lichaw
quotes.context: Provides a strengths-based operating model: apply a superpower intentionally while explicitly managing its “overuse” downside.

quotes.topic_title: Live coaching: Lenny’s peak experiences and themes
quotes.text: But when you're a super senior executive, at some point you can't be solving problems for everyone. And if you're just in the weeds solving problems all day, that's when you're not doing your real job and you're going to be the whole team and your whole company nuts.
quotes.speaker: Donna Lichaw
quotes.context: Counterintuitive leadership guidance: a strength (problem-solving) becomes a liability at senior levels if it keeps you in the weeds.

quotes.topic_title: Live coaching: Lenny’s peak experiences and themes
quotes.text: Look for things that give you energy because there's something there.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Actionable heuristic for identifying strengths and direction: energy is a signal worth following and analyzing.
